Name: Butane
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: 1,3-Butadiene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (2004): the lower explosion limit is 1.1vol%. Those containing stabilizers are classified into Division 2.1 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#1010)

Name: Tetrafluoroethylene
Rationale for classification: The lower explosion limit is 10vol% (NFPA (13th, 2002)). Those containing stabilizers are classified into Division 2.1 (UN#1081) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

Name: Dimethylamine
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: Hydrogen
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: Carbon black
Classification: Not applicable(Materials of animal or vegetable origin and mineral origin)
Rationale for classification: Solid (GHS definition)

Name: N-methyldithiocarbamic acid
Rationale for classification: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition. The free acid cannot be classified due to lack of data.

Name: diborane(6)
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because "the flammable range is 0.8-88 %" (ICSC, 1990; Hommel, 1991) and it is ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG No.1911, Class: 2.3(2.1)

Name: chlorophenol
Rationale for classification: Not Gas (GHS definition) (o-, m-, p-)

Name: diazomethane
Rationale for classification: Ignitable if there is an ignition source, because of "its auto-ignition temperature: 100degC" (ICSC(J), 1995)

Name: oxalonitrile
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG No.1026, Class: 2.3 (2.1)

Name: Ketene
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because the flammable range with air is 12.5% and the lower flammable limit is 5.5-18 vol%. (It is ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air)

Name: Formaldehyde
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (2004): the lower explosion limit is 7vol%. There is no applicable substance listed in the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods (gas). Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition (aqueous solution)

Name: bromoethylene
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: methyl nitrite
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG No.2455, Class: 2.2

Name: Carbon monoxide
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because the flammable range with air is 12-75% and the lower flammable limit with air is 12 vol%. (It is ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air.)

Name: Methane
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: Bromomethane; Methyl bromide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (1999): the lower explosion limit is 10vol%. Not classified as "Flammable/Combustible Gas" by the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods. A special provision sets forth that the substance is "combustible under limited conditions" (UN#1062 (those not exceeding chloropicrin 2%)). Bromomethane is "regarded as a special case depending on the regulatory purposes" according to the criteria for "flammable/combustible gas" in GHS.

Name: Ethane
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: Ethene
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: Ethyne
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: Chloromethane; Methyl chloride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (2000): the lower explosion limit is 8.1vol%. Classified into Division 2.1 (UN#1063) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Methanamine
Rationale for classification: Flammable range with air is 4.9-20.7 vol%.

Name: Methanethiol
Rationale for classification: Flammable range with air is 3.9-21.8 vol%.

Name: Propane
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: 1-Propyne
Rationale for classification: Flammable range with air is 1.7-11.7 vol%.

Name: Chloroethane
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (2004): the lower explosion limit is 3.6vol%. Classified into Division 2.1 (UN#1037) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Chloroethylene; Vinyl chloride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (2000): the lower explosion limit is 3.6vol%. Those containing stabilizers are classified into Division 2.1 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#1086)

Name: Ethene, fluoro-
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: Ethanamine
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of UNRTDG Class: 2.1and "the flammable range with air is 3.5-14 vol%" (ICSC(J), 2002, etc.) (It is ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air, according to GHS criteria)

Name: Ethylene oxide
Rationale for classification: The lower explosion limit is 3 volume % (ICSC 2004)- i.e., Category 1. Classified into Division 2.1and Division 2.3 (UN# 1040), according to UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods.

Name: Ethene, 1,1-difluoro-
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: Trimethylamine
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.1

Name: 1-Chloro-1,1-difluoroethane; HCFC-142b
Rationale for classification: The lower explosion limit is 6.2vol% (ICSC (1999)). Classified into Division 2.1 (UN#2517) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Ammonia
Rationale for classification: Flammable range with air is 15-28 vol% (GESTIS-database on hazardous substances, 2nd, 1993)

Name: Arsenic acid
Rationale for classification: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition (aqueous solution)

Name: germanium tetrahydride
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because "the flammable range with air is 95.2-97.2%" (Hazardous Materials DB, 2nd, 1993) and the lower flammable limit is 0.8-2.8 vol%. (It is ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air.)

Name: Hydrogen sulfide
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Class: 2.3, Subsidiary risks Class: 2.1

Name: Dihydrogen selenide
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data is available, though classified as "flammable gas" by ICSC(2004). Classified into Division 2.1 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods (UN#2202))

Name: Arsine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (2004): the lower explosion limit is 4.5vol%. Classified into Division 2.1 (UN#2188) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: phosphine
Rationale for classification: Ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume in air. UNRTDG Subsidiary risks Class: 2.1

Name: Stibine
Rationale for classification: Because of a lack of data (Explosive, when mixed with air, according to ICSC (1999), though the literature shows no explosion limits). Classified into Division 2.1 and Division 2.3 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#2676)

Name: silane
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because the lower flammable limit is 1.37-100 vol%.

Name: Chlorotrifluoroethane
Rationale for classification: Non-flammable (1-chloro-2,2,2-trifluoroethane) (ICSC (1999))
